Hovey — 3*
It Is interesting to note that the man who carried the veto of Christian
Democratic party directors on the Aldisio appointment to Premier Pella was
Amintore Fanfani. And it was Fanfani who went back a second time to plead
with Pella not to make the appointment.
That was interesting for these reasons; first, Fanfani vigorously ad¬
ministered the beginnings of the land reform as minister of agriculture in
De Gasperis cabinet? second, Fanfani is leader of the so-called “Democratic
Initiative faction that has fought to keep the Christian Democrats on the
road to social and economic reforms; a left-center faction that provides a
counterforce within the party to the conservative wing which Aldisio repre¬
sents; and, finally, Fanfani had served Pella loyally as minister of the in¬
terior and was slated for reappointment to that important Job in the revamped
cabinet.
But two points need emphasis here;
The first is that the Aldisio affair does not mean that the left-of-cen-
ter faction is in firm control of the Christian Democratic party.
And the second is that Pella’s troubles with his party were deeper and
broader than simply a quarrel with the party’s left wing over the agriculture
ministry.
Fanfani was spokesman for the party directors on the veto of Aldisio. but
this does not mean that Fanfani’s 11 Democratic Initiative* faction can run the
party or chart overall party policy. As a matter of fact, ^Democratic
Initiative is only one of three fairly well defined left-of-center groups
within the sprawling, heterogenous Christian Democratic party. All the
Aldisio affair means so far as the party is concerned is that on this issue
the Fanfani group, with the support of De Gasperi, was able to make its policy
tk© policy. Only in that context was the veto of Aldisio, achieved at
the cost of a cabinet crisis, a victory for the Deft wing of the Christian
In that connection, it should be noted that Pella’s intention of appoint¬
ing a right-wing Christian Democrat — Attilio Picoionl — as vice premier and
foreign minister in the revamped cabinet — was quite acceptable to the party.
In fact, the party may have suggested Piccioni for the Job. It is interesting,
then, to add the additional fact that Picoionl was the soonaor of Aldisio for
the agriculture ministry.
But the fact that Picoionl was acceptable to the party as number two man
in the cabinet Illustrates the point that the left wing is not in firm con¬
trol of the Christian Democracy* You might say that the left wing had to
accept right-winger Piccioni as vice premier and foreign minister in order to
put over its party veto of Aldisio as agriculture minister. But the Piccioni
matter gets me back to my second point* that Pella’s troubles with his party
were broader than Just the Aldisio affair.
The fact is that Pella has never been a “party man,* in the sense in
which politicians use that term. He was elected to parliament as a Christian
Democrat and he served with distinction as budget minister in the De Gasperl
cabinet. But one writer has said of him that although he lived for eight
years in the midst of politics, he had as little to do with it as possible.
As I reported previously on this program, Pella was the choice of the
party to head the government after the summer cabinet crisis. H® was selected
